translation.en: [narrator] Still awake?
Well, you're not alone.
On some nights,
falling asleep or staying asleep can feel really tricky,
translation.ko: 잠들거나 깨지 않는 것이 정말 힘들 때가 있어요

translation.en: and we all know that being tired is just no fun.
translation.ko: 다음날 피곤할 게 뻔한 데 말이죠

translation.en: So in this series,
we'll explore the latest in sleep science.
We've interviewed and collaborated with top sleep researchers and doctors
translation.ko: 수면 연구가 및 전문의와의 면담과 협력을 통해서

translation.en: to bring you information
that can help you develop good sleep habits
and put them into practice now.
And I'll show you
that, for many people, mindfulness and meditation
are among the best ways to getting a good night's sleep
translation.ko: 숙면을 취하고 산뜻하게 아침을 맞이할 수 있는

translation.en: and to waking up rested, restored, and refreshed.
At the end of every episode,
I'll guide you through wind-down techniques
translation.ko: 제 안내에 따라서 이완 명상을 실시하는데

translation.en: that you can return to again and again
to help you get to sleep.
translation.ko: 수면에 도움이 될 수 있을 거예요

translation.en: In this first episode,
we're going to explore myths about sleep.
translation.ko: 잠에 대한 근거 없는 믿음을 살펴보겠습니다

translation.en: There is so much misinformation out there,
translation.ko: 넘쳐나는 잠에 대한 잘못된 정보 중에서

translation.en: so we'll look at what's true and what's not.
So, welcome to the first series
translation.ko: 첫 수면 시리즈에 오신 걸 환영하며

translation.en: where we hope you won't make it to the end credits still awake.
translation.ko: 각 에피소드가 끝날 때쯤에는 주무실 수 있길 바랍니다

translation.en: Hi. I'm Eve,
and I'll be your guide on a journey to better sleep.
translation.ko: 여러분의 숙면을 돕는 가이드가 되어 드리겠습니다

translation.en: When it comes to a good night's rest, everyone has their own theories.
translation.ko: 하룻밤 푹 자는 방법에 대한 사람들의 생각은 모두 달라요

translation.en: It's nearly impossible to know what to believe.
translation.ko: 뭘 믿어야 할지 결정하기 힘들 정도죠

translation.en: Let's start with a piece of conventional wisdom
translation.ko: 먼저 제가 어렸을 때부터 들었던 일반적인 통념 한 가지를

translation.en: I know I was raised with.
The old "everyone needs eight hours of sleep a night" myth.
translation.ko: 바로, 누구나 하루에 8시간은 꼭 자야 한다는 믿음이에요

translation.en: Well, it turns out eight isn't a magical number.
translation.ko: 하지만 8시간이 누구에게나 통하는 마법의 숫자가 아니라

translation.en: It's more of an average than an actual goal.
Yes, the sweet spot does lie somewhere
translation.ko: 따라서 성인의 경우 최적의 수면 시간이

translation.en: between seven and nine hours for adults,
and I know that's the case for me.
But it varies from person to person and can change over a lifetime.
translation.ko: 하지만 이 시간은 사람마다 다르고 살아가면서 계속 바뀔 수 있어요

translation.en: What about the saying, "You can never get too much of a good thing"?
Unfortunately, it seems you really can,
translation.ko: 하지만 지나치면 좋지 않은 것도 있어요

translation.en: whether it's too many sweets or too much sleep.
Did you know that regularly sleeping more than nine hours a night
has been linked to diabetes, heart disease, and other problems?
translation.ko: 당뇨병이나 심장병과 같은 질병과 관련이 있다는 사실을 아시나요?

translation.en: But what's more important than counting hours
is listening to your body and understanding what it needs.
translation.ko: 우리 몸에 필요한 것이 무엇인지에 귀 기울이는 것입니다

translation.en: Still, it's true, tracking time is a habit that's hard to kick.
translation.ko: 하지만 시간을 추적하는 것은 버리기 힘든 습관이죠

translation.en: In fact, it's probably where the "I don't need to worry
translation.ko: 실제로 이러한 습관으로 인해서 주말에 잠을 몰아서 자면 되니까

translation.en: about how much sleep I get during the week
because that's what weekends are for" myth comes from.
translation.ko: 주중에는 잠이 중요하지 않다는 믿음이 생겼는지도 모릅니다

translation.en: The answer to that one is complicated.
translation.ko: 이러한 믿음에 대한 답은 간단하지 않아요

translation.en: Yes, you can make up for an occasional bad night
by sleeping in,
but when your sleep-wake schedules swing back and forth every week,
translation.ko: 하지만 수면 시간과 기상 시간이 매주 바뀐다면

translation.en: it can lead to health issues.
Well, then you might think in that case,
translation.ko: 그렇다면 이렇게 생각하실 수도 있을 거예요

translation.en: "Why not cut down on sleep altogether?"
In other words, what about, "I'll sleep when I'm dead"?
translation.ko: 죽으면 실컷 잘 거니까 지금은 잘 필요가 없다는 말이죠

translation.en: That saying might be true technically,
but it's also true that to get more out of life, you need enough sleep.
translation.ko: 인생에서 더 많은 것을 얻으려면 충분한 수면이 필요합니다

translation.en: Sleep is like food.
Sure, you can limit yourself to a few hundred calories a day,
translation.ko: 하루에 몇백 칼로리로 제한할 수는 있지만

translation.en: but you'll end up with huge health problems as well.
translation.ko: 그렇게 되면 건강에 심각한 문제가 생기게 되죠

translation.en: You need a certain amount of food and sleep
translation.ko: 생명을 유지하는 것뿐만 아니라 잘 살기 위해서는

translation.en: not just to stay alive but to thrive.
Prolonged and extreme sleep deprivation
can have serious ramifications when it comes to your health.
translation.ko: 건강에 심각한 영향을 미칠 수 있습니다

translation.en: This next one may really surprise you.
The common recommendation that exercising at night is bad for sleep is overblown.
translation.ko: 수면을 방해하므로 밤에 하는 운동을 피하라는 권고는 과장된 것으로

translation.en: In fact, one study showed it's quite the opposite,
that for most healthy people,
working out at night doesn't adversely affect the ability to sleep.
translation.ko: 밤 운동은 수면에 부정적인 영향을 끼치지 않습니다

translation.en: It may actually help you fall asleep
translation.ko: 오히려 쉽게 잠들고 더 오래 숙면을 취하도록

translation.en: and spend more time in deep sleep.
The caveat is that doing a high intensity workout
less than an hour before hitting the hay
is probably not a good idea.
You need to give yourself a few hours
to let your body temperature come down and your heart rate to regulate.
translation.ko: 심장 박동을 조절하는데 몇 시간이 걸리기 때문이죠

translation.en: Okay, so by now,
you might agree that getting a solid night's sleep is important.
translation.ko: 잠을 푹 자는 게 중요하다는 사실에 동의하실 거예요

translation.en: So how do we achieve this?
translation.ko: 어떻게 하면 잠을 푹 잘 수 있을까요?

translation.en: If you are an adult, some might say a glass of wine
translation.ko: 취침 전에 마시는 와인 한 잔이나 칵테일이

translation.en: or a cocktail before bed will help you unwind.
translation.ko: 취침 전에 마시는 와인 한 잔이나 칵테일이 긴장을 풀어준다고 말하는 성인이 있을 거예요

translation.en: Sleep specialist Dr. Jason Ong of Northwestern University
translation.ko: 수면 전문가인 노스웨스턴 대학의 제이슨 옹 박사에 따르면

translation.en: says that alcohol may help you fall asleep quickly.
translation.ko: 알코올을 섭취하면 쉽게 잠들 수 있습니다

translation.en: After all, it is a sedative.
But chances are you won't sleep as deeply once you do nod off.
translation.ko: 하지만 깊은 잠을 자지 못할 가능성이 큽니다

translation.en: That's because alcohol suppresses REM,
the stage of sleep that's associated with memory consolidation
translation.ko: 기억 강화와 정서적 안정에 영향을 미치는 수면 단계인

translation.en: and emotional well-being.
What's more,
alcohol also increases the likelihood of snoring,
translation.ko: 알코올을 섭취하면 코를 골 가능성도 커지는데

translation.en: and I'm sure we've all experienced that.
And it can all add up to a bad night's sleep.
translation.ko: 이 모든 것이 숙면에 지장을 줄 수 있습니다

translation.en: So if you're of drinking age and you do want that cocktail,
translation.ko: 음주가 가능한 연령이고 칵테일 한 잔을 마시고 싶다면

translation.en: consider this.
Your body can process alcohol at about one drink per hour,
translation.ko: 우리 몸의 알코올 분해 속도는 한 시간에 약 한 잔이기 때문에

translation.en: so try to finish your last drink at least two hours before bedtime.
translation.ko: 취침 전 최소 2시간 전에는 마지막 잔을 비우는 게 좋습니다

translation.en: That should give you enough time to eliminate alcohol from your body,
so it doesn't impact your sleep.
Okay, so if alcohol comes with a warning,
what about coffee?
What about that assumption, "All caffeine is bad for you"?
translation.ko: 카페인은 무조건 나쁘다는 가정은 과연 맞을까요?

translation.en: I know that caffeine has long been demonized as the enemy to sleep,
translation.ko: 카페인은 오랫동안 수면의 적으로 여겨져 왔습니다

translation.en: and sure, it does stay in our systems longer than alcohol.
translation.ko: 알코올보다 체내에 더 오래 머무른다는 사실은 분명하지만

translation.en: But that doesn't mean, as adults, we have to kick the habit.
translation.ko: 성인의 카페인 섭취를 중지할 필요는 없어요

translation.en: Coffee or tea are generally fine
if you just keep an eye on timing and quantity.
Two or three cups a day before 5:00 p.m. are no problem for most people.
translation.ko: 오후 5시 이전에 마시는 2-3잔의 커피나 차는 대부분의 경우에 문제가 되지 않지만

translation.en: It may become problematic if you drink more or later than that.
translation.ko: 더 많은 양을 마시거나 그보다 늦은 시간에 섭취하면 문제가 될 수 있습니다

translation.en: So, what's the biggest sleep myth out there?
translation.ko: 그렇다면 수면과 관련해서 가장 잘못된 믿음은 뭘까요?

translation.en: There might be one we all cling to,
that there's a single, surefire trick to dozing off,
translation.ko: 잠들 수 있는 단 한 가지의 확실한 비법이 있고

translation.en: and if only we knew what it was, our lives would be perfect.
translation.ko: 그것만 알면 우리 삶이 완벽해질 거라는 생각입니다

translation.en: The truth is
there isn't a single technique that works for everyone.
translation.ko: 모든 사람에게 도움이 되는 단 한 가지 기법은 없습니다

translation.en: Not only that,
the more effort we put into it,
the more we try to hack sleep
translation.ko: 온갖 비법과 규칙 그리고 요령을 사용해서

translation.en: with tricks and rules and techniques,
the more it works against us.
One approach that doesn't seem to be a myth
translation.ko: 근거 없는 믿음이 아닌 한 가지 방법으로는

translation.en: is meditation and mindfulness.
Studies have shown that practicing meditation
can calm the nervous system,
and deep breathing generates a feeling of serenity as well.
translation.ko: 심호흡이 마음의 평온을 가져온다는 사실이 밝혀졌습니다

translation.en: This is why meditation is great for anyone seeking better sleep health.
translation.ko: 따라서 명상은 더 나은 수면 건강을 찾는 모든 사람에게 좋은 방법이 될 수 있습니다

translation.en: It can help us let go of that rigid mindset
that keeps us from drifting off.
So now, if you're ready to relax,
let's begin the wind-down exercise.
Before you do anything else,
I'd just like you to take a moment to get comfortable.
translation.ko: 잠시 시간을 내어서 몸을 편안하게 해주세요

translation.en: Even if you don't usually go to sleep on your back,
let's begin the exercise by lying flat or leaning back comfortably.
translation.ko: 반듯하게 눕거나 편하게 기댄 상태에서 명상을 시작하겠습니다

translation.en: You can have your knees bent slightly if you'd like.
But just enjoying that feeling
of the body letting go and relaxing,
sinking into the surface beneath you.
We're going to begin tonight's exercise
with a little breathing routine.
So first, just bringing the attention to the breath
and just noticing where you feel it.
In the nose,
the throat,
the chest, or the diaphragm.
And we're going to be taking a deep breath in for four,
translation.ko: 넷을 셀 동안 숨을 깊이 들이마시고

translation.en: holding it for four,
and then breathing out for six.
So, are you ready?
Let's begin.
So breathing in for four.
…two, three, four.
Hold it for four.
…two, three, four.
Now breathing out for six.
…two, three, four, five, six.
In for four.
…two, three, four.
Holding it for four.
…two, three, four.
Out for six.
…two, three, four, five, six.
In for four.
…two, three, four.
Holding for four.
…two, three, four.
Out for six.
…two, three, four, five, six.
In for four.
…two, three, four.
Holding for four.
…two, three, four.
And out for six.
…two, three, four, five, six.
Great.
Now just returning the breath to normal.
Next, we're going to do a very simple visualization.
Just imagining a steady flow of warm sunlight
gradually filling the body up from the feet.
So starting at your feet,
that warm sunlight
dissolving any tension,
any discomfort
as it starts to fill the body.
Filling up the toes
one by one.
Moving up through the feet and the legs.
Experiencing the qualities of warmth,
space,
and ease…
as it continues to travel up through the body.
Up past the waist…
to the back and the stomach.
It's as though that sunlight
just washes away any discomfort.
And it continues up through the chest and the back.
Into the shoulders
and down the arms.
All the way down to the hands and the fingers.
A sense of relief in the body
and stillness in the mind.
As it continues to travel
up through the neck…
and the throat.
Into the head
and face,
all the way to the very top of the body.
Until there's nothing other
than that sense of stillness remaining.
So if the mind feels very active still,
then you can allow the body to continue resting as it is,
translation.ko: 그 상태로 계속해서 몸을 쉬어 주세요

translation.en: but mentally, slowly
begin to count backwards
from a thousand to zero.
A very steady pace.
Not rushing it.
Not trying to fall asleep.
Just focusing on counting
on one number to the next in reverse.
translation.ko: 숫자 하나하나에 집중해서 거꾸로 세어 봅니다

translation.en: And knowing that it really doesn't matter too much when sleep comes.
translation.ko: 잠이 언제 오는지는 크게 중요하지 않습니다

translation.en: But as you lie there in this way…
both the mind and the body
are getting all the rest that they need.
If you're still awake…
…and interested in learning more,
check out the next episode in our series,
where we will focus on how our devices keep us up at night
translation.ko: 전자기기가 어떻게 우리의 수면에 영향을 미치는지와

translation.en: and what we can do to break out of technology's strong grip on our sleep.
translation.ko: 이러한 기기의 강한 유혹에서 벗어나는 방법에 대해서 알아보겠습니다

translation.en: See you then.
